DOC.HEAD: Member of Noriega Defense Team Seeks To Extract Himself from Case
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One of four Florida lawyers representing ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega has asked to be allowed to quit in part because of public statements by the other attorneys in the case. ``It was a question of drawing the line between function as a lawyer and a general spokesperson,'' attorney Neal Sonnett said Thursday. He said he'd rather not discuss his other reasons for withdrawing. ``I have consistently refused to comment on Panamanian affairs _ they are outside my responsibility,'' he told The Associated Press. ``It's important for me to practice law.'' ``I didn't really want to create a firestorm,'' he added. ``There have been other conflicts between me and co-counsel but nothing I feel is appropriate to discuss.'' Sonnett filed a motion Wednesday with the U.S. District Court asking that he be allowed to quit representing Noriega on federal drug charges filed in Miami in February 1988. The court usually grants such requests. Although Sonnett in recent months has indicated that he was pulling back from the case, both Frank Rubino and Raymond Takiff, also Noreiga attorneys, said they were surprised by Sonnett's motion. ``We've had no problems whatsoever,'' said Takiff. ``Just general differences of opinion.'' Takiff said he found Sonnett's move puzzling, especially since Sonnett recently appeared on CNN's ``Crossfire'' and spoke of Noriega. Sonnett countered that he appeared on the news show as president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers to discuss forfeiture of attorney's fees. He said he didn't talk about the general. A fourth Noriega attorney, Steve Kollin, said he had no comment. Noriega was seeking asylum at the Vatican Embassy in Panama City.
